import React from 'react' import * as BooksAPI from './BooksAPI' import './App.css' import {Route} from 'react-router-dom'; import SearchLibrary from './SearchLibrary'; import Shelf from './Shelf'; import MyLibrary from './MyLibrary'; class BooksApp extends React.Component { state = { showSearchPage: false, queryResult: [], books: [], currentlyReading: [], wantToRead: [], read: [] } componentDidMount() { BooksAPI.getAll() .then((response)=>this.setState({books:response})) .then(()=>{ this.state.books.forEach((book) => { switch(book.shelf) { case 'currentlyReading': {this.state.currentlyReading.push({book})} break; case 'wantToRead': {this.state.wantToRead.push({book})} break; case 'read': {this.state.read.push({book})} break; } }) }) .then(()=>console.log(this.state.currentlyReading)) } addToShelf(book, shelf) {} render() { return (
{this.state.showSearchPage ? (
this.setState({query: e.target.value})} />
    ) : (

    MyReads

    Currently Reading

      {/*
    1. To Kill a Mockingbird
      Harper Lee
      2. */}
    2. Ender's Game
      Orson Scott Card

    Want to Read

    1. 1776
      David McCullough
    2. Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
      J.K. Rowling

    Read

    1. The Hobbit
      J.R.R. Tolkien
    2. Oh, the Places You'll Go!
      Seuss
    3. The Adventures of Tom Sawyer
      Mark Twain
    )}
    ) } } export default BooksApp /** * TODO: Instead of using this state variable to keep track of which page * we're on, use the URL in the browser's address bar. This will ensure that * users can use the browser's back and forward buttons to navigate between * pages, as well as provide a good URL they can bookmark and share. */
